thread.title: Employers tackle recruitment racism

title: Employers tackle recruitment racism
text:
Employers vow to tackle recruitment racism Sarah O’Connor and George Parker Backbencher threatens to challenge Corbyn 
Some of Britain’s biggest employers have promised to hide young job applicants’ names during the recruitment process as part of the government’s push to tackle discrimination in the labour market. 
A group of public and private sector organisations, which employ about 1.8m people between them, have agreed to use “name-blind” recruitment for graduates and apprentices, where recruiters do not see applicants’ names until after they have shortlisted them for interview. 
Names make a difference: government research published in 2009 found that UK employers were far more likely to offer interviews to people with white-sounding names than non-white ones, even though their applications were otherwise identical. 
David Cameron described this as “disgraceful” in his Tory conference speech in Manchester, when he promised a new push on social mobility. 
“You send out your CV far and wide but you get rejection after rejection — what’s wrong?” he asked. “It’s not the qualifications or the previous experience. It’s just two words at the top: first name, surname.” 
Mr Cameron’s promise to tackle discrimination partly reflects his “compassionate Conservatism” agenda, but it is also partly to dispel any fears that his crackdown on Islamic extremism is racially divisive. 
He will announce today that the civil service, the BBC, the NHS, learndirect, local government and the Conservatives will implement name-blind recruitment, together with private sector companies HSBC, Deloitte, Virgin Money and KPMG. Teach First, one of the UK’s biggest graduate employers, already hides applicants’ names. 
The government hopes the practice will spread more widely through the private sector. It cannot eliminate discrimination on its own, though, not least because it only covers the initial stage of sifting through application forms. In addition, most companies only plan to use it for graduates and apprentices. In the civil service, it will be used for a wider range of roles, but not for those at Senior Civil Service level. 
The prime minister’s spokesperson said that was because some recruiters would use headhunters to find top external people, when individual reputations were important. She said it was most important to tackle discrimination at the start of people’s careers. 
The government’s push on discrimination coincides with a growing realisation within some large companies that they will have to change their recruitment processes if they want more diverse workforces. Deloitte recently decided to hide the schools and universities of applicants from its recruiters, for example. 
At the same time, the government is ratcheting up the pressure on employers to tackle gender discrimination . It announced on Sunday that it would force large companies to publish information on the average bonuses they pay to their male and female workers as part of its gender pay gap disclosure rules. Women’s hourly earnings are on average 9 per cent lower than men’s, although the gap has almost closed for full-time workers under the age of 40. 
The government also plans to extend its target for women to take up one in four seats on company boards to publicly listed businesses in the FTSE 350 share index. 
This year for the first time businesses in the FTSE 100 hit the government target for 25 per cent of their board members to be female. 
A third of FTSE 350 companies told a FTSE/ICSA survey this summer that they would not reach the target by the end of the year, and nearly two-thirds had no plans for how they might do so. 
The 25 per cent target originated in an interim report by Lord Davies of Abersoch, published in 2011. Lord Davies is due to publish his final report this week.
